sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: We shal haue as little conscience anon in robbery.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: I, should we rob hospitals, our betters haue made that a monoply, but to steale from a rich Iew it is no more sin then to vnload a weary Asse.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: By hooke or crooke you will haue it.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: We were bred in a country that had the charity to whip begging out of vs, when we were yong, and for staruing, manhood denies it, you know what must necessarily follow.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Nay make your conclusion.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p:
Presse her in a dumbe shew, heere abouts should be
the house, great windowes and a little wicket, noble man-like, what's heere a ladder of ropes, S'foot we are preuented, S. Nicolas Clearkes are stept vp before vs.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Were they ten iustices Clearkes wee would share with 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.p: There Maisters would preuent vs for that, yet since our case is desperate, we will put in with 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Softly for waking the maids.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: S'hart, thou art the sonne of a lapland-witch sure, this is the maids chamber, one of them is in a dreame, she fetcheth her wind short I am sure

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.p: How long thou art poking at it, what is't man?

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: Some light commodity or other.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: A womans lower part, it is altogether in fashion for them to be light about the bumb indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: I haue the male part too't, the dublet, your women will haue it euer in request to haue the mans part vppermost.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: S'hart, a French slop, these are none of the Iewes trouses, and they should be no gallants, for hee hath mony in his purse.

sp.speaker: 1. Sail.
sp.p: I marry fir, this fellow had good ware about him indeed, vpon my life we are little better then bauds, get mony by others Venery, this Iew is a

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: 2. Sail.
sp.p: Water, water, water

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire, the slaues lie on straw-beds, and yet this cry will take no hold on 'em, fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Flames and brimstone, I am in hell, Zounds my breeches, the ladder, this Iew hath found vs out and fir'd the house.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Deere sir conteine your selfe.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A plague on venery, a hot end comes on't still, is the window high enough that I may breake my necke, dye any death rather then be roasted?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Here's a vault leads to the common shower, it being low-water the sheetes shall let you downe to your escape.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Those sheets haue brought me low enough already. Within Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Flames stop thy throate.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Deere sir aduenture it and saue your life.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Were it to hell I must,
A plague on whoores say, whose vast desires
Beginnes in watry teares and end in fires.

div.stage: Enter Rabshake at one dore, and Iew at another.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: An Ocean ouerwhelme thee, where is the fire slaue?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: At the Iewes house, Benwash his house, your house sir:

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: My bags, my obligations, my wife Agar I say, I shall runne mad, I will scale the windowes, burne for company, my money and my selfe will go together, what's heere a ladder of ropes, Gallops breeches, burne on, burne on, sindge all the world, consume it with thy flames, thou best of elements, burne on I say.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: As you are men on this side help to saue our goods.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: As you are ministers of Lucifer let it burne on, it's myne owne house, come but on my ground I'le haue my action for't.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: He is distracted, helpe as you are men.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Dogs, villains, theeues, downe with him that laies a hand a to't, be iust you powers of heauen, and throw thy wild fire downe vpon the heads of these adulterers, roome, roome, roome, I haue it, I haue it, roome, roome, roome.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: The Iew is mad indeed, his losse distracts him, speak gentle friend, doth the fire slacke.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.p: The house is saued, but all the ships in the harbour Vnquenchable do burne.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The ships in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Rub.
sp.l: Yours onely excepted.

sp.speaker: Frans.
sp.l: My thoughts now haue their ends,

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Do not thou grieue boy, know I loue thee
Thy maintenance shall expresse it, I haue friends
And iewels left for thee, but I hate thee more
Then all thy wealth made me loue thee before

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: False woman, thou shalt not shake me off thus
Were all the impudence of thy whole sexe,
All there blushlesse impieties confin'd in thee
I'le moue thy flinty heart to sence and shame,
I will thou sorceres: now I do see to late
There is a hand ore-rules our will and fate.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This shews the greatest plague heauen keeps in store Fals, when a man is linkt vnto a whore.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I haue it, I haue it, heere, heer, nay come on, you haue come off I am sure, here's euidence looks pale to thinke but on't, you do not know the tennant to this cottage, hee was an vpright dealer, hee paid mee to a haire, come forward and bee hang'd, I shall aduance you in a ropes name, you haue made no cuckold of me. I made my selfe one, pandred my owne hornes, now sirrah, you that go to't by art, put your cases one in the necke of another, your rem in re what thinke you of this case.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I thinke the serpent crept into a narrow hole, and left his case behind him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Then I am a Cornuto.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: This make's the naked truth appeare so.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: The best is, the crest is mine owne, I paid well for't.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: Deere husband pardon me, I will confesse,

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: What wilt thou confesse? that thou hast made a meere Asse of me, to pay thy iourney-man wages before hand.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It should seeme he labour'd hard to earne it, he could keepe no cloathes about him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: This slaue doth not thinke I'le cut his throate for this, you haue watcht neerely sirrah, you haue.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Vnlesse I should haue bene their baud, I could watch no neerer, me thinkes she hath done you a great pleasure, rid you of your disease, iealousy, now you need feare no more, you are in possession on't, your doubts are at an end.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Good, very good, my doubts are at end, but I shall hang you in suspence for this: you Manticora that plumpe vpon raw flesh, here set your hand to this letter, that I may draw your Captaine on againe vpon the breach, I'le blow you
vp else, why moue you not, I am sure you laid your hand to the businesse when time was.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I know my life is forfeit
To your iust anger, nor will I be the meanes
To shed more bloud, myne shall suffice alone,
Since onely one is wrong'd punish but one.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: She loues him still, I am a cuckold
He has out-gon me, do you heare; subscribe
Moue me no further.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: The worst can be but death, I will not.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I tel thee I'le for giue thee, giue my reuendge
Scope but at him, thou art free.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Sweare it by Abrahams dust, the ashes of our fore-fathers.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: Dust and ashes it's but a fraile oath.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: By that, and all that ties a vertuous mind,
I vow and sweare by written writ.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: You'le sweare as much to forgiue me I hope to sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Why, thou shalt be the messenger, nay the actor
In my iust vengeance.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: The hang-man you meane sir, I am expert at it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Francisco, what newes man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The worst your eares can heare, our ships

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: They are vntoucht, of all they are onely safe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You dazell your owne eyes, that villaine Dansiker
Hath grapled them and fled.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Whirle-winds pursue him, heauen, seas, earth, all at once
Ioyne to his confusion, now I do see too late
There is a hand ore-rules our will and fate.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: I shall then take your promise, your brother being redeem'd, this night I shall enioy thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: This Diamond binds me to't, by this I sweare.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: 'Tis thine I will bestow it on thee, to tie thy faith
Thou hast his ransome.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: 'Tis heere.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: About it then, now fortune equall proue
I am happy, yet her lust redeemes my loue.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Yet see, midst all my miseries I haue a friend,
My constant loyall Voada, could what we enioy
Make a man happy, I am not miserable.
Thou com'st to comfott me, I know thou doest.

sp.speaker: Vo.
sp.l: This fellow raues sure: do you know to whom you speake?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Put not a further triall on mee, thou best of women:
Know if this arme were bar'd all other meanes
From hearts of Christians, it should digge thee food.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: We know you are a bloudy murderer, and are repaid
By our iust Prophet, that hates false Runnagates.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: How couldst thou mallice man so much, heaven,
As to create a woman?
Thou hast forgot me sure: oh looke on him
That hath deny'd his faith, sold all his hopes
To purchase thee his bride.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: To match with beggery: know I contemne thee
As a most abiect slaue, and hate thee more
Then all thy wealth could make me loue before.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What meane you sir? could you expect a good,
A happinesse from hell? she is a whoore.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Thou liest: this arme shall make it good,
My soule for her I lost, and now my blood.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Your passion doth transport you, here comes her pander,
One that knowes all her secrets: examine him,
If she stand cleare, let my life answere it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Il'e put you to the Test.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I haue had a hot night of this, nothing but fire in my mouth two houres together: mary the old Iew my maister I heare hath stumbled on a cooler. I thought this Captaine would bee comming so long on vpon the breach hee would breake his necke at the last. This venery is a tempting dish, some ner'e lin licking at it till they burne their lips. Well, I must go comfort vp old Benwash, hee's heauy vpon his wiues lightnesse.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: You Iew, a word with you?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p:
You Turke, I haue nothing to say to you: Ha, ha, ha,
poore fellow, how hee lookes since Mahomet had the handling of him? hee hath had a sore night at Whose that knockes at the backe-doore? Cry you mercy, I thought you were an Italian Captaine.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Zounds, leaue your circumlocutions, Il'e send your head to your heeles else.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You parcell haud, all vsher, answere directly who 'tis beares a way the prize in your Mistresses race, or Il'e spoyle your footing, cut you off by the hammes.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Alas sir!

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Speake, who are her suters?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Voadi's suters? oh sir, a Barbar sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Il'e make you haue need of a Surgian er'e I haue done with you. How do you know hee is a Barber?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: He smels strong of Rose-water, and he hath never mony in his purse but on Saturday-nights.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: What other suiter, slaue?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: An other sweet youth too, I take it a Comfet-maker; and it seemes hath rotten teeth, for he dares not come in sight so long as the Barber's in the way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This dogge deludes vs, Il'e teare thy throat out villaine, vnlesse thou instantly name him she loues.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Her Page sir, the little Christian, the good fac'd Captaine gaue her, Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: My slaue, the French Ship-boy?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I saw him leaue her now. How do'st thou know she loues him?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Shee makes him sing bawdy songs to her, lookes fortunes in his fist, & babies in his eyes, makes dialogues betwixt him, her little dogge, & her selfe: lies vpon her backe, puts his hand in her hand, & wrings it till the teares come againe.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Insatiate monster, could her swolne blood Reach such a height none but my Page must sute her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Containe your selfe a while, this slaue can speake One of her dialogues.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It is my practise sir: you shall stand for the Lady, you for her dogge, and I the Page: you and that dogge looking one vpon another, the Page presents himselfe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.l: The best is behinde sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Iew, slaue, dogge.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: The horned Divell follow him. A Skippers boy?
The shame of woman? rather then be baffeld thus
I will betray this towne, blow vp the Castle:
Francisco, do but second me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: First repossesse your selfe of your strong hold,
I feare some trechery: the Governor
With all the Ianisaries of the towne
I met in their way thither.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Blast them ye powers first. The Governor
Make towards the Castle? I am betraid, away,
I see that heaven forgets not though I delay.
Thrust out by Ianisaries?

sp.speaker: Ianisa.
sp.l: Packe hence false Runnagate,
Slaue, Beggar.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Disgratious vassals, what mountain covers me?
Winke, winke, thou Day-star, hide my guilty shame,
Make me as if I ner'e had beene, whose name
Succeeding times wil curse: should I confesse my sin,
Ther's not an eare that can with pitty heare
A man so wicked miserable: should I beare vp,
Out-looke my crimes, I want meanes to support me.
To dye I dare not, the iawes of hell do yawne
To swallow me: liue I cannot: Famine threats,
And that the worst of poverty, contempt and scorne.
Never on man Fate cast so blacke a frowne,
Vp I am denied to flye, vnpittied downe.
Rest restlesse soule on this accursed soyle,
And teach the world into how sad a toyle
Ambition and swift ryot run, when meane content
Sits low, yet happy: and when their day is spent
All that they get is labour and vnrest,
A hatefull graue, and worst, a troubled breast.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Where shal I find this most vnfortunat wretch?
There is a part in him cald man, which we should pitty
How er'e his merit stands, nor will I leaue him,
Though he hath left himselfe. See where he lyes
Best suiting with his fortunes, could we our fate foreknow
Men were as Gods, nor need we haue laine so low.
How fare you brother? why with so sad an eye
Do you behold me, that in your miseries
Beare equall part?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Can there remaine a soule that will vouchsafe
Compassion on me? thou doest but flatter,
Or hast forgot, I haue lost all, and pouerty
When no ill else will doo't, makes all friends flye.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Were you intitled to no other guilt,
How willing for you should my bloud be spilt?
Heere sir, accept this poore reliefe
Bootlesse alas distresse recounts those errors
To thinke what might haue been cures, not the terrors
Of present suffering.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: True, true, Francisco, could I redeeme the time,
The world should speake my penitence.
Could I call backe but one seven yeares,
Though all my life were seruile after,
Were my soule but free
From innocent bloud, and fearefull blasphemy,
On the condition I might liue an age
Tortur'd vpon a wheele.
I tell thee friend,
Were I this Cities Vice-roy, I would giue
My crowne, dispoyle my selfe of all, onely to liue
One month with that content this soule did know
When a poore Fisherman possest it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You are too low dejected.
Men that with sufferance their wrongs do beare
Are held but weake, and States more oft for feare
Then loue vnto the right, redresse mens ils.
Who stoutly downe his enemies, malice kils,
Who basely wounds himselfe.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: No lesse then truth, I haue beene too low indeed
Each one the yeelding grasse doth dare to tread
That flies resisting thornes, falfe Voada,
Thy Lambe is turn'd a Lyon, I feele reuendge
Giue a new life to me, I'le onely stay
Till I haue spoke thy brother, I thinke he'le blush
To heare thy shame, tell thee thou hast not plaid
A womans part with me, suppose the worse
That he turne villane to, he had better curse
His grand sirs ashes, if once more I fall in
I'le be vnparaleld at least for sinne.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Stay see the strumpets loue, Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Captaine, you are the man I seeke, I haue a suit to you,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Concerning Voada, is't not?

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Concerning her that hates you for my sake
Neglects your merit, this night giues full reuendge
To all her iniuries.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Repeat that happy word againe, I am wholly thine.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Know her vassaliat lust hath long pursued,
And with such violence attempted me,
That with my oaths this night to sate her heate
I hardly haue delaid her.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What's this to my reuendge?

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: It follow's, giue me but way
Through your Castle there's a Hollander
This euening makes from hence
That giues them passage.
I haue tied him to't

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Thou art for euer free, the houre name,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: I'le speak your worth yet, in spight of fame
About three, watch the word Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Avoid suspicion and till then be gone.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Nay then my ioyes do flow,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Whether tends this? what passage, come you for him?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: To heauen I once more must exact
Thy trust and diligence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Speake it.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Make instantly to Voada, tell her
This night a skipper doth attend to steale aboard
Her loue Fidelio, giue her the houre and place
Wish her to pistoll him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Wouldst haue her kill her to.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: I, and runne made for't, meane while I'le walke the streetes I shall meete some will know me to whom I will relate my wrongs, wilt do't Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My soule to gage.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: This comfort then in spight of hell I'le haue,

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.l: went not vnreuendg'd vnto his graue.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: How blacke a path unbounded riot treads,
Your gentler eyes haue veiw'd. Our Scoene now leads
To giue him rest, that from his ills had learn't
To know his misery, and at least had earn'd
This lesson from the extreams, that others past
No course that violent is, secure can last.
This clue doth wind him backe, and Dansiker,
The wealth of Tunis, now is become there feare,
Striues to redeeme his infamy and with successe,
Makes through their bowels to his happinesse.
No sooner hee arriues in France, but his sad eares
Insteed of welcomes entertaine new feares,
The aged Oke that Atlas-like susteyned,
The weight of France, that with his bloud regain'd
Her wasted body, like the Pellican
By one that from his life tooke breath is slaine,
This fatall blow, astonisheth the hopes
Of Dansiker, and his, to make returne,
Impossible those fires yet fresh doe burne,
Would threaten them with vtmost tortures heere
To make aboad, they finde themselues beset
With many they by their spoyle made foes, yet
Twixt two extremes they chose the better part
Take land and to the Gouernor present
Themselues and fortunes, shew their act, intent
And poenitence, their promised pardon, what befell
This shew presents, which words deny to tell.

div.stage: Enter Gouernour in state, takes his seate, Dansiker and his followers with ropes about their neckes, their weapons with the points towards them, deliuer their petition, the Gouernour reades and salutes them, put vp their swords, suddenly rush in diuers like Merchants with followers, seeme to threaten the Gouernour, who defends Dansiker, labours betwixt them, seeme pacified, and Dansiker sweares by his sword, offer to go out to meete his wife and child, they perswade, he deliuers them to the Gouernours trust. Omnes Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Twixt hope and dread, as suited former merit,
The Gouernour receiues them giues new spirit
Vnto their drooping hopes, when with the name
Of Dansikers arriuall, swift wing'd fame
Brings in the oppressed Merchants, whose spoyle
Had fed his hungry sword, and with their toyle
Made rich his rapines, these craue law, his life
The opposing Gouernour almost ends the strife,
With his owne bloud, informes them, the Kings death
Stood onely bar to his safety, that his breath
Would recompence all former iniuries,
To approue it giues them notice of the prise
Brought from Tunis, and more to assawadge their ire
Dansiker dare, what act they can desire
Man to accomplish, to redeeme his peace
And their great losses, all their furies cease.
And with one voyce demand Benwash the Iew
As his iust ransome, they need no more renew,
This their request, by oath themselues they tye.
To bring him prisoner, or in the action dye.
No motiues from his wife or child diswade,
This his resolue, suppose he now hath made
His backe returne and in some apt disguise
Attends successe vnto his enterprise
His end and strange preuention, briefly shew
Designes are mens, their sway the gods do owe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: This is the place a cold bloud thwarts my heart,
My fleeting soule in her disturbed passion
Proclaims some ill neere, let me suppose the worst
Aliziaes dead, false tongue how durst thou name
So great a mischiefe? alas this bracelet speakes it,
This which I tied vnto her iuory wrist
The witnesse of those vowes confirm'd vs one,
The news of my captiuity tooke all her hopes
And life away, and dying she bequeath'd
This loyall gift againe, with my sad ransome.
'T may be this youth may be Alizia
Her selfe a prisoner, yet shee's to vertuous
To out-liue her honour and her chastity,
Which her captiuity must needs indanger:
I heare his foote-steps.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: We are not far off from the place, softly, softly.
The night is darke and friendly to myne ends.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Fidelio, Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: 'Tis he would rob me of Fidelio,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Fidelio I say yong Raymond heere

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Shoote.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: So I am slaine.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Thus dost thou beare Fidelio back againe,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Oh false, false Alizia thy watch-words as thy selfe
Deceiuing, didst thinke my slauery
Was not an ill sufficient, but my bloud
Must pay thy falshood tribute, or couldst not wish
So great a plague to me, that I should heare
Thou wert turn'd prostitute, vngentle cruell woman,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: T'is not the boy sure, his voyce, his passion
Speakes him another, more proiects yet, I heare some foot stir.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: How fearefull is the night, heauen's angry sure,
And hauing drawne the day vp, chid her thus
For giuing light to mens impieties.
'Tis much about the houre of my appoint,
What sad groane wounds my eares, Fidelio,
Raymond, friend Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Or rather Infidelio, what ere thou art
Thou needst not doubt thy taske, thou hast made me sure,
Or if thou doubts it, here dischardge one bullet more.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: 'Tis not his voyce, thou liest falfe thoughts, Raymond, Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My name is Raymond, that Fidelio vniustly murdered.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: No maruaile though thou thundrest heauen;
And darts thy flashes downe, oh! why is not
This world a vniuersall fire? what one good
Keepes backe thy flames?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Oh speake! what art thou? whose sad speech
Makes death stay yet to heare thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: My friend, my Raymond by my meanes murdered
I haue liu'd too long, too long.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Oh speake! what art thou whose sad accents force
Pale death to stay and heare thee.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Alas I am nothing, nothing.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: As thou hast hope in heauen tell me thy name,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.p: I will, my name's Alizia, thy constant loyall, loyall friend, that in her passage vnto thee will not be long

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Oh saue thy life.

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: Wish me not so much ill, I loue thee better.
Miracle of thy sexe, oh let me imbrace thee yet.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Heere, heere, flye hence vaine breath,

sp.speaker: Aliz.
sp.l: No other good is knowne to me but death, moritur

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Francisco thou'rt a villaine, forgiuenesse Voada,
The words of these two innocents with purple eyes
Dart terrour through me, Fidelio turn'd a woman.
Within Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Voad
sp.l: I will rather giue an eare to the blacke shrikes
Of mandrakes, thou knewst I lou'd him
And that hath forct his wound, at sight whereof
Methinkes reflecting heauen should spred it selfe
In a deepe crimsome vaile, blush to haue created
A wretch so monstrous, but my reuendge sleepes, know boy
I will repay thy death, slaue I will famish thee,
And when thy fainting eye-lids gin to cracke,
My satisfied lust, by him most hates thee,
Shall be thy obiect.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: You wrong me to suppose I should be guilty
Of such an impious deed.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Doth not thy bloud stain'd poniard speake it
With which thy accursed arme did force his breast
His too too gentle breast.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Thy selfe be witnesse.

div.stage: Stabs at him, he beats it backe, and wounds her.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.p: That I am reuendge on thee, murder, murder, the slaue will murder me.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: What meane you wife?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: As you are men make rescue of me.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I am betray'd, out-gon by a shee diuel.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: He hath not onely slaine his innocent page,
But thus assail'd my life, lay hands on him
Deere countrimen reuenge my wrongs, my bloud
On this false runnagate, I faint, I faint.
Conuey me to a Chirurgion, make him safe.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi
sp.p: In the Gouernours name I do command you giue your weapons vp.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: S'hart Gentlemen, you know Francisco kil'd him, I'le make it good.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.p: Wee haue nothing to charge you with about your page It is the wounding your wife with an vnlawfull weapon.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p: You haue most vnmanly thrust in a woman.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: Honest friends, Turkes, and Officers, if euer I laid hands on her, may I neuer see light more.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.p: We'le take a reasonable order for that, you nere laid hands on her, out impudence away to the dungeon with him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.p: S'hart carry me to the Gouernour that I may haue iustice first.

sp.speaker: 2. Offi.
sp.p:
The fellow raues, he thinks men in office haue nothing to doe but to giue him iustice, you must first be punisht
and then talke of iustice when you haue cause.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.p: Away with him, he shall know what 'tis to marry into a great Tribe, an honourable Tribe: you vse a great woman as if she were your wife, ye'ar a base fellow indeed. You a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Nay, then I see my end drawes, I shall raue,
Run mad: haue you er'a Bedlam, that I may not famish
But shew trickes to get meate with, or raile against the State:
And when I haue eas'd my gall a month or two
Come out againe. Zounds let me beat hempe,
Doe any thing rather then famish: That death
She hath vow'd me, and Il'e prevent it: allow me
But every weeke a Christian, I am content
To feed vpon raw flesh, if't be but once a month
A Brittaine, Il'e be content with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Offic.
sp.l: Nay then you are mad indeed, away with him.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: As you are true Turkes, I will put you in sureties,
I know the Divell will prouide me bale,
Rather then loose my imployment: as you are pittifull Turks.

sp.speaker: 1. Offic.
sp.l: Nay then we shall be troubled with you.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Plagues, pestilences, all fall vpon my head
Rather then by a whoore be famished.
I do coniure you.

div.head: Scoena vltima.
div.stage: Enter Benwash, Rabshake, at severall Doores.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Is this childe of Adam comming yet? hee that will eate of the forbidden fruite though he loose Paradice fort, is he comming.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: As fast as his legges will beare him, considering the vse he meanes to put them to. I haue provided a Caudle to comfort him with.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
That's my deere pretious villaine, how sweet art thou
Reuenge? the thought of thee turnes all my bloud to aire.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And your hornes too sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: All light Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: They were begot light, but methinkes they should be heauy in the wearing.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I will make them abortiues man, smother them in the wombe.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Though you lop the branches, you will preserue the tree to beare more fruit, I hope, your wife sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: She shal downe too, I will let her bloud in a new veine she shall turne vp the white of the eye, and dye the death of a sinner.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How will you dispence with your oathes sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Tush, by equivocation man, I will not hurt her, but thou shalt by equivocation, behinde the Arras, my deere Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: That word (by equivocation) lyes on my stomacke, I would be loath it should make me cast vp my gall, I would not haue my throat cut by equivocation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The game is rows'd, take thy stand and strike Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Strike you sir? you are the keeper, and haue the fees in possession, I haue no mony vpon this equivocation.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: So the houre of my redemption is at hand, for mans worst hell, a whoore.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You put me to a sweet purgation the other night, 'twas well feare tooke away some of my sences, I had smelt for't else.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: You saw the necessity of it sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You may call it necessity. I thought of the day of Iudgement, and that was more then euer I did in my life before: what with the fire aboue, and the Ram-headed Divell your husband below, I imagined damnation could not bee farre off.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Good, excellent good.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
And whither is that golden calfe of Horeb, that Iew of the the Tribe of Israel gone, that it is Iubile with you
now, all open?

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Hee is rid to the Goletto about taking in a commodity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: And in the meane time thou wilt vtter one at home, I am thy Merchant Wench, and will deale with the by whole-sale.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Rather by retaile sir, retaile.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Where is your Pim Rabshake, taking a nap at the staire foot, committing sin in conceit, whilst we are at it in action? hath he the two qualities of an Vsher, a good eare, and to indure cold of his feet? haue you giuen him instructions?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I see how it did worke, I feele it.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Hee'l make the old Iew beleeue I was his wiues bawd.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: The slaue was borne Pander, his mother was a Midwife, and then he must needs be bawd to set his mothers trade aworke.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You will grone for this anon sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.p: I pray you sir sit downe, a small banquet sir.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Provocatiues and whetters on? one licorous thing drawes out another. Who will not sweare Venery is a sweete sin now? Bacchus and Venus, two Gods, the Divell is farre enough off then.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: You are deceived sir, he is at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Is Dunne in the mire? for old acquaintance sake wee'l dragge you out sir: you are in travell, I am the sonne of a Midwife, Il'e helpe to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: It cannot be, I am in a dreame.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: A good beleefe doth well; were I in your case, I should be past dreaming: but Il'e cast you in a slumber sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: You must bee at your sweet meates: cannot Mutton serue your turne, but you must haue sauce to it?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: This Whoore hath betraid me: now she hath wrung what she can out of me, she hanges me vp for a dryed Neats-tongue. She is an insatiate Whoore sir, hath intic'd me by the Pander your man: I was chaste before I knew her sir.

sp.speaker: Rabsh.
sp.p:
Beleeue him not sir, he is a meere Goate, looke on
his beard else.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: You may see by his haire hee is a man of hot Liver; he came over me with such violence I had not the heart to resist him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I beleeue you wife, I beleeue you, and thou shalt iustifie it to his teeth before the greatest Divell in hell. Rabshake giue her a Mittimus, strangle her.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Haue you forgot your oathes sir?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I sware as I was a Turke, and I will cut your throat as I am a Iew.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Villaine, keepe off, I say.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You should haue said so when time was Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: Thou betraiest thy selfe slaue, makest way to thine owne destruction.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Stop her throat, I say, giue no eare to her.

sp.speaker: Agar.
sp.p: I do confesse my sin, I haue wrongfully betraid thee.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I find my selfe in bonds for't Lady, it is some comfort yet, that I dye not vnreveng'd.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Thou speakest charitably. Is she gone? is her lust satisfied now?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Do a woman to death, and she will bee satisfied, nothing else will.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Now for you M. Gallop: you gaue it me with tilting, and I will returne your curtesie.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Saue my life sir, and I will be your slaue, sell my selfe in open market, brand me.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: That were Lex talion indeed, one marke for another: but it will not serue the turne. Haue at you.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, how the Oxe goares him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: 'Sdeath villaines, trecherous villaines, the plague, pox.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: He died a true letcher, with the pox in his mouth. Why this was valiantly done sir, in single opposition.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: why now my brow begins to smooth. How lik'st this Tragedy, Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Rarely, if it do not proue a Tragedy to vs sir, i'ts but a Comedy hitherto: the setting off is all.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Tush, the best is behind man: doe'st thinke I doe not
beare a braine about me? Beware a polititian, man: heere, binde me, binde me, hard, hard.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I mary sir, I like this well, a man may trust you when your hands are tyed behinde you.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I cannot choose but laugh to thinke how happy I am in my proiect: it will amaze thee when thou hear'st it Rabshake, wee shall so gull the innocent world, laugh at the silly world.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: If you gull me now, Il'e giue you leaue to make mummy of me: what's next sir?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Heere, take this dagger, stabbe mee an ynch into the breast and arme.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Do you call this gulling of the world?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I cannot but laugh at the gentlemans lecherous voyage to Lucifer: there, there. Now Rabshake let me binde thee.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: How? binde me?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Thou art not capable of the mistery, thou art shallow Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I doe not desire to wade deeper in I thank you sir, I am no polititian, beare no braine about me sir; yet I can diue into a knaues pockets as well as any man, your worship knows.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: What doest thou meane by this?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: To rob you as I am a Turke, & cut your throat as I am a Iew, you haue forgot your equivocation; Il'e chop logicke with you. Come, your rings, your chaine: do you not laugh? haue you not gul'd the world fairely?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Thou hast mistaken me: know thou art all my care.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And you would be rid of me, I conceiue you sir, though I am no polititian: I haue seene the play of Pedringano sir, of Pedringano sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Deere Rabshake, vpon my knees I do intreat thee heare me.
For whom haue I tane thought, out-watcht the night
Out-toyl'd the day, but for my Rabshake? what friend,
What kinsman, what heire had I but Rabshake?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Yes, you meant I should haue beene your heire.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
Nay, thou shouldst haue had all in possession, my purpose was to haue liu'd a private life, done penance for my sins,
and given thee all.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: You would haue parted with this chaine, these rings and gold.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: They are thine own, on whom should I bestow them else?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And you haue a trick to come off cleere with this businesse.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: In spight of ielousie, without suspition man: you being bound, your head thrust in this circle, as if tied vp for starting, I had cried out theeues, murder, rais'd the street, transferd the act vpon some stranger.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And I should haue beene your heire.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Thou wrongst me to make question of't.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: If I should try him, it is beyond my compasse if hee out-saile me: this chaine and gold is mine.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: 'Sfoot my selfe too.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: For once Il'e try you: heere binde me, if you do outreach me, Il'e ner'e trust Iew more.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Heere, heere: Is thy head in?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: It is sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Haue I caught you? are you in the noose? you haue seene the play of Pedringano sir, Il'e play with you.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: 'Sheart I am your slaue sir, I did it to make your worship merry.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Tush, you are my heire, Il'e hang you vp a airing.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: As you are a man heare me sir.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: You must haue your chaines, you shall be chayn'd, I could euen cracke my sides with laughter. This will affoord me mirth vnto my dying day. The play of Pedringano? how the weesell hangs! Ha, ha, ha. Theeues, theeues: Murder, murder. I shall betray my selfe with laughter. Were you caught Rynard? are you in the noose? Murder, murder, thieues murder.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Breake ope the doores, the voyce speakes from this roome.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Inhumane deed! what hand could be so bloudy?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Speake, who was the murderer?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Helpe me to a Surgean.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Runne for a Surgean. Tell by what monster was this act (so full of horror) done?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Three strangers rusht in suddenly, wee being at supper, all my seruants forth, saue honest Rabshake: and hauing rifled vs, did act this horride murther.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Here is a Surgean.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: The Prophet Mahomet reueale the homicides.

div.stage: Enter Gouernor, other officers, Sare, Ferd. Alb. Dansiker disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.p: What moues these out-cryes?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: Behold a bloudy murder, Benwash, his wife,
This Captaine, and his seruant.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My honest seruant, honest Rabshake.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Benwash murdered? he hath saued me a labour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Is there any hope of life in him?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: His wounds are sleight, sir, onely his faint-heart makes them dangerous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Take courage man. Speake, hast thou any knowledge of the Murderers?

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.p: Onely he sayes they are strangers, men of the sea.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Canst thou remember in what habit, what men of person and complexion they were?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: What meanes the slaue to eye me so?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: That fellow in the stammell hose is one of them.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: On me? Villaine, thou buy'st my bloud
At a deere rate. O thou immortall God
Who know'st my innocence! that for his former sins
Hast guiven vp, Dansiker into the hands
Of these damn'd miscreants.

sp.speaker: Omn,
sp.l: Dansiker?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I Dansiker, that would with all your deaths
Haue cancelled his former infamy,
Left to the world a president of valour,
Writ in your sad confusions: but heauen is iust,
Christians did fall by me, by slaues I must.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p:
Call forth the common Hangman, by this time he hath
done his office on Francisco. Dansiker? vnlook't for?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Heare me before I dye, I do confesse
Mine owne hand did these murthers. Dansiker
Hath iustly done me vengeance.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: How's this? thou done these murthers thy selfe, being bound and hurt? Thou rau'st sure.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I did them sir: the cause my wife prou'd false, vntrue,
Beare witnesse, though I liu'd a Turke, I dye a Iew.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Out Dogge, Divell.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Vnheard of Monster! Cast his loathed carkasse
Vnto the common aire. Never did day discover
Two such inhumane Caitifes, stretch out his armes,
You haue your traines and fire-workes, apply your Torches
Vnto his breast. Wee'l know what proiect now
Lead you vnto this second venter.

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: I will confesse it willingly: It was to haue conueid
This Iew from hence, haue made a massacre
Of the whole Towne, dasht out the miscreant braines
Of your yong Infidels.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.l: And art not sorry, Dogge?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Yes Dogge, I am sorry, and confesse my crimes
Preuented such a merit: I was not worthy
To do heaven so good a seruice.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Pull off his hatefull flesh, digge out his heart
By peece-meal.

sp.speaker: Muff.
sp.l: Wilt thou turne Turke, and saue thy soule yet?

sp.speaker: Dans.
sp.l: Yes Pagan, villaine, I will. Forgiuenesse heauen,
Let my example moue all Pyrates, Robbers
To thinke how heavy thy revenging hand
Will sit vpon them. I feele thy iustice now,
Receiue my soule, accept my intended vow.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: So, convey his hatefull body to the same place,
The Iew doth lye vnburied.
sp.stage: Enter at seuerall doores Voad and Ward.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Iustice, let mee haue Iustice, worthy Gouernour.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Giue her no eare, she is all woman dissimulation.
I am a Turke, and I do craue the law.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.l: He hath wounded heere a Turke, a Lady, and
We craue sentence according to his merit.
He may receiue the Bastinado, pay a fine.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Pay a fine, what fine, from one that's famished,
For want of a poore asper, set me to sea againe,
The tenth of what I'le bring you in, shall countervaile
The reuenew of the Indies.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: The slaue is mad, we'le send you far enough,
Lady depose the for't, you shall haue iustice.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: By our great Prophet Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: You do me wrong, let me in priuate speake to her
Ere she betray my life, it is no lesse
Then your owne law affoords me.

sp.speaker: Turk.
sp.l: The weakenesse of her body brookes it not.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: How say you Voada, can you afford him speech?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: I'le giue his vaine words hearing, though to much paine
Oh my deepe wound let all remoue from hence.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Had she a heart of brasse I' de pierce it, leaue vs all.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Now sir your motion,

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Wherein hath my desert stro'd so much ill
To straine thy hate, to this a high beyond,
What we seeme malice, I lou'd that face so well
To purchase it I exchang'd my heauen with hell.
And to be bar'd what I so deerely paid for,
I'st not a plague sufficient? but thy faith
Must now be sold, to be a vengeance greater,
To pay me vngratefull hire, canst thou behold
These eyes stroke inward, as asham'd to view
The fires which first betraid them, this mind, body,
That doth conteine a soule more blacke and dismall
Then is the rauen night, these armes, that haue so oft
Made to thee rules of loue, now famished
For want of what thou surfets on, canst without teares
Behold my miseries?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Prodigy of woman, dost laugh?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: This is true musicke, could I inioy these tunes
My selfe would be thy Iaylor.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Why then thy wound is not dangerous?

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: A meere scratch, know that I am reueng'd
Of my Fidelios death, and as thy tortures
Each houre increase, so shall my harmony
Till vengeance period giue vnto thy destiny.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: I will discouer thy hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Voad.
sp.l: You are preuented, help, I sound, I fall.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: As low as hell there keepe thy festiuall.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Hold murderous villaine, all tortures man ere knew,
Shall be inflicted on thee.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Inhumane dog.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I laugh at you.
Here's a preseruatiue, against all your poysons
True Balsamum for villany, who will soare high
First lesson that he learn's, must be to dye.
Heres precedent for him, you're slaus of Mahomet
Vngratefull curs, that haue repaid me thus
For all the seruice that I haue done for you,
He that hath brought more treasure to yuor shore
Then all Arabia yeelds, he that hath showne you
The way to conquer Europe, did first impart,
What your forefathers knew not, the seamans art;
Which had they attein'd, this vuiuerse had bene
One Monarchy: may all your seed be damn'd
The name of Ottaman be the onely scorne
And by-word to all Nations; may his owne slaues
Teare out the bowels of the last remaines
Vnto his bloud-propt throne, may ye cut each others throate:
Or may, oh may the force of Christendome
Be reunited, and all at once require
The liues of all that you haue murdered,
Beating a path out to Ierusalem,
Ouer the bleeding breasts of you and yours.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Vnheard of monster.

sp.speaker: Ward.
sp.l: Lastly, oh may I be the last of all my country
That trust vnto your tretcheries, seducing tretcheries,
All you that liue by theft and Piracies,
That sell your liues and soules to purchase graues,
That dye to hell, and liue farre worse then slaues,
Let dying Ward tell you that heauen is iust,
And that dispaire attends on bloud and lust:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Downe with the villaine.

sp.speaker: Gou.
sp.l: Teare the wretch peece-meale, throw his accursed limbs
Into the raging bowels of the sea.
His monument in brasse wee'le thus ingraue,
Ward sold his country, turn'd Turke, and died a slaue.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: WHo writes and thinkes to please the generall tast,
Where eyes and eares are fed, shal find he hath plact
His worke with the fond Painter, who did mend
So long, that striuing to please others, gaue no end
To his owne labours; for vs, and if not all
We know we haue pleased some, whose iudgements fall
Beyond the common ranke, to whom we humbly yeeld
Our selues and labours, they best deserue to sheeld
The worthy workes of Time, and with their view
To grace choyce Pennes, and such we hope are you,
To whom we owe our toyle, and willing giue
All right in this, your fauour makes it liue.
Stand faire vnto our ends then still, and crowne
With gentle hand this worke which now's your owne.
